articles.headline: Adjusting, More M.D.’s Add M.B.A.
articles.snippet: Once there were five or six joint M.D./M.B.A. programs at the nation’s universities, but now there are 65 as more doctors realize health care is a business.
articles.abstract: Once there were five or six joint M.D./M.B.A. programs at the nation’s universities, but now there are 65 as more doctors realize health care is a business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under heavy pressure from government regulators and insurance companies, more and more physicians across the country are learning to think like entrepreneurs.

articles.headline: Life in Syria’s Capital Remains Barely Touched by Rebellion
articles.snippet: While protests against the government of Bashar al-Assad break out across Syria, many Damascenes insist on another reality.
articles.abstract: While protests against the government of Bashar al-Assad break out across Syria, many Damascenes insist on another reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — As protests broke out across a restive Syria on a recent Sunday, and crowds were dispersed yet again by gunfire that left many dead, the conversation in the capital dwelled not on the uprising but rather on nails, along with the choice of polish and hair color and the latest in makeup trends.

articles.headline: Closed, Says Google, but Shops’ Signs Say Open
articles.snippet: In recent months, many perfectly healthy businesses across the country have expired according to Google Places, and fixing the error has often been difficult.
articles.abstract: In recent months, many perfectly healthy businesses across the country have expired according to Google Places, and fixing the error has often been difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: In mid-August, Jason Rule learned some surprising news about the coffee shop that he owns and operates in Hays, Kan.: the place had closed for good.

articles.headline: Hybrid in a Trade Squeeze
articles.snippet: A debate over consumer subsidies and technology sharing is shaping up as a crucial test case.
articles.abstract: A debate over consumer subsidies and technology sharing is shaping up as a crucial test case.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — For General Motors and the Obama administration, the new Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid represents the automotive future, the culmination of decades of high-tech research financed partly with federal dollars.

articles.headline: A Congresswoman’s Cause Is Often Her Husband’s Gain
articles.snippet: In championing kidney care, Representative Shelley Berkley of Nevada has often taken actions that have benefited the business interests of her husband, a doctor.
articles.abstract: In championing kidney care, Representative Shelley Berkley of Nevada has often taken actions that have benefited the business interests of her husband, a doctor.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — At the University Medical Center here, alarms were set off three years ago — kidney transplants were failing at unusually high rates, and some patients were even dying.

articles.headline: Leak Offers Look at Efforts by U.S. to Spy on Israel
articles.snippet: New details have emerged in the case of an F.B.I. translator who was sentenced last year to 20 months in prison for leaking classified information to a blogger.
articles.abstract: New details have emerged in the case of an F.B.I. translator who was sentenced last year to 20 months in prison for leaking classified information to a blogger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Shamai K. Leibowitz, an F.B.I. translator, was sentenced to 20 months in prison last year for leaking classified information to a blogger, prosecutors revealed little about the case. They identified the blogger in court papers only as “Recipient A.” After Mr. Leibowitz pleaded guilty, even the judge said he did not know exactly what Mr. Leibowitz had disclosed.
